title: How to Calculate Equivalent Annual Cost (EAC)

steps.title: Determine the price of the asset.
steps.content: Determine the price of the asset. [1] X Research source For example, suppose you are comparing two analyzers, A and B, costing $100,000 and $130,000, respectively. These are the Asset Prices.

steps.title: Determine the expected lifespan for each.
steps.content: Determine the expected lifespan for each. [2] X Research source Suppose Analyzer A is expected to last 5 years, while Analyzer B is expected to last 7 years. These are the number of Periods.

steps.title: Determine your discount rate.
steps.content: Determine your discount rate. [3] X Research source Discount rate is the cost of capital, or how much return your capital is required to generate each year. Say your organization uses a Discount Rate of 10%. Determine the annual maintenance costs for the asset. [4] X Research source Suppose Analyzer A has an annual maintenance expense of $11,000, while Analyzer B has annual maintenance expense of $8,000.

steps.title: Plug the numbers into the equation Asset Price x Discount rate / (1-(1+Discount Rate)^-Periods) + Annual Maintenance Costs.
steps.content: Plug the numbers into the equation Asset Price x Discount rate / (1-(1+Discount Rate)^-Periods) + Annual Maintenance Costs. [5] X Research source It should be apparent that Analyzer B is the more cost effective option, with a net savings of $2,677.03 a year, compared to Analyzer A. For Analyzer A, EAC = $ 100 , 000 ∗ 0.10 ( 1 − ( 1 + 0.10 ) − 5 ) + $ 11 , 000 = $ 37 , 379.75 {\displaystyle {\text{EAC}}=\$100,000*{\frac {0.10}{(1-(1+0.10)^{-5})}}+\$11,000=\$37,379.75} For Analyzer B, EAC = $ 130 , 000 ∗ 0.10 ( 1 − ( 1 + 0.10 ) − 7 ) + $ 8 , 000 = $ 34 , 702.72 {\displaystyle {\text{EAC}}=\$130,000*{\frac {0.10}{(1-(1+0.10)^{-7})}}+\$8,000=\$34,702.72}
